Project Description  The  Project  supports  the  Government’s  efforts  to  improve 
madrasah education so it meets national education standards, 
within the Government’s broader education policy and strategic 
framework.  The  Project  will  cover  primary,  junior,  and  senior 
secondary private and public madrasahs in 27 poor districts of 
Central  Java,  East  Java,  and  South  Sulawesi  provinces.  The 
Project will benefit 120,000 students in 500 madrasahs. 
The Project will support a mixture of demand- and supply-side 
interventions to enable project madrasahs to (i) improve teacher 
professionalism;  (ii)  upgrade  teaching–learning  resources  and 
facilities; (ii) increase their internal efficiency; and (iii) strengthen 
their governance, management, and sustainability. The Project 
will help madrasahs meet national education standards according 
to the needs identified in madrasah development plans, through a 
range of interventions, including teacher qualification upgrading 
and professional certification, provision of substitute teachers, and 
teaching skills development; upgrading or expansion of facilities 
(classrooms,  libraries,  and  laboratories);  and  provision  of 
teaching–learning materials. These interventions will be selected 
by individual madrasahs according to their development needs.  
The  Project  will  enhance  the  internal  efficiency  of  project 
madrasahs  by  increasing  enrollment,  decreasing  dropout  and 
repetition  rates,  and  increasing  completion  rates  at  all  levels 
through remedial and scholarship programs, particularly for poor 
and  female  students.  Governance,  management,  and  financial 
sustainability  of  project  madrasahs  will  be  improved  through 
training and performance-based madrasah development planning 
and  management,  and  advocacy  programs  to  enhance  the 
perception  of  madrasah  education  quality  and  encourage 
stakeholder participation to ensure better resource mobilization 
and transparency. 
   
Rationale  Under the new national education law (20/2003), madrasahs were 
formally integrated into the national education system as equal 
partners with general (secular) schools. To further this integration, 
Parliament recently issued a directive to the Ministry of National 
Education (MONE) (covering general education) and the Ministry

ii   
of  Religious  Affairs  (MORA)  (covering  Islamic  education)  to 
formulate a common policy and strategic framework for national 
education development by the end of 2006.  
 
Ensuring a better madrasah education system and its continued 
sustainability  is  pivotal  to  achieving  the  Government’s  key 
education goal of universal 9-year basic education, as well as the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDG) for education and gender 
equity. Demand for madrasah education is growing: it constitutes 
13% of total primary and secondary enrolments, in predominantly 
private, community-based institutions. Madrasahs are particularly 
attractive to the poorest rural students, who are also the hardest 
to reach, and so can help meet MDG targets. Madrasahs also 
attract more girls than general schools and so will be key in the 
Government’s efforts to reach gender equity in senior secondary 
education and beyond.  
The  quality  of  madrasah  education  is  low.  Many  madrasahs, 
especially private ones, will be unable to meet the new national 
education  standards  for  learning  outcomes  and  the  teaching–
learning  environment  (e.g.,  qualified  teachers,  good  facilities, 
available textbooks) without additional investment. The Project will 
meet  the  transitional cost  of  attaining  these new  standards  in 
selected  poor  madrasahs  through  a  mixture  of  supply-  and 
demand-side support. This will help secure continued demand for 
education in these madrasahs. At the same time, the Project will 
support policy dialogue that ensures the effective use of projected 
increased Government funding for madrasahs, and the long-term 
financial sustainability of a better madrasah system.  
The Project will support teacher upgrading, instructional materials, 
rehabilitation  or  expansion  of  facilities,  student  scholarships, 
school  governance,  and  management  development,  to  be 
financed  through  school-managed  block  grants.  These 
interventions are recognized as key determinants of quality and 
standards  improvement,  as  set  out  in  the  national  education 
standards. 
 
The  Project  will  promote  and  enable  more  results-oriented 
planning  and  management  systems  at  all  levels,  through  a 
combination of organizational and network development at school, 
community,  district,  provincial,  and  central  levels.  This  will 
facilitate coordinated planning and management in what remains 
a comparatively centralized system. At the same time, the Project, 
through  policy  dialogue  and  assurances,  will  help  harmonize 
strategy, programming, and financing between the two ministries. 
In this way, the Project will pursue the Government’s goal of a 
national  education  system  of  equal  partners,  with  madrasah 
students, even those in poor private madrasahs, having the same 
opportunities as students in general schools.

iii
 
Impact and Outcome  In partnership with the Government and other funding agencies, 
the Project is expected to help increase the levels of educational 
attainment and productivity of new workers and the rates of formal 
employment and household incomes. The project objective is to 
improve madrasah education, resulting in better student learning 
outcomes in core subject areas, raised madrasah accreditation 
levels, and enhanced perceptions of madrasah education quality 
by parents and the community. 
   
Project Investment Plan  The  project  investment  cost  is  estimated  at  $71.4  million, 
including taxes and duties of $0.1 million. 
   
Financing Plan  The  total  cost  of  the  Project  is  estimated  to  be  $71.4  million 
equivalent.  It  is  proposed  that  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB)  provide  a  loan  of  $50  million  from  its  Special  Fund 
resources, with a maturity term of 32 years, including a grace 
period of 8 years, and an interest charge of 1.0% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% thereafter.

Implementation  The Executing Agency for the Project will be MORA, with the 
Arrangements   Directorate  General  of  Islamic  Education  responsible  for  the 
overall management of project implementation. A project steering 
committee  (PSC)  will  be  established  to  guide  the  CPMU  on 
general policy directions, inter-sectoral coordination and strategic 
directions. The PSC will comprise representatives of the Ministry 
of  Finance,  the  National  Development  Planning  Agency 
(Bappenas), MONE and MORA. The secretary general of MORA 
will chair the PSC. The director of the Directorate of Madrasah 
Education will be the PSC secretary. The PSC will be supported 
by  a  project  technical  committee  (PTC)  that  will  consist  of 
representatives from MOF, MONE, and MORA. The PTC will be 
chaired by the Director of Religious Affairs in Bappenas. A central 
project management unit and three provincial coordinating units 
will be established, assisted by project consultants, advisers, and 
facilitators to provide technical and implementation support. 
   
Executing Agency  Ministry of Religious Affairs 
   
Procurement   All ADB-financed procurement for goods, services, and works for 
the  Project  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (April 2006, as amended from time to time). Supply 
contracts  for  goods  and  services  estimated  at  more  than 
$100,000 up to $500,000 will be awarded on the basis of national 
competitive  bidding,  while  contract  packages  of  $100,000  and 
below  will  follow  shopping  procedures.  Madrasah  civil  works

iv   
contracts for rehabilitation of classrooms, libraries, and computer 
and science laboratories, which are expected to cost less than the 
equivalent of $30,000, will be awarded on the basis of community 
participation. For remote madrasahs with only one supplier, direct 
contracting  is  allowed.  For  economy  and  efficiency,  several 
madrasahs  could  pool  their  procurement  for  more  competitive 
bidding. 
   
Consulting Services  All consultants to be financed from the proceeds of the loan will 
be selected in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (April 2006, as amended from time to time). Project 
implementation  consultants  (60  international  and  183  national 
person-months)  will  be  hired  through  a  firm  of  international 
consultants in association with national consultants, using quality- 
and cost-based selection. The main areas of expertise will be 
teacher  professional  development,  madrasah  leadership 
development,  madrasah-based  management,  teaching–learning 
assessment and quality assurance, performance management, 
and  project  management.  Consultants  for  monitoring  and 
evaluation  studies  and  training  programs  will  be  hired  using 
consultants’  qualifications  selection  or  single  source  selection 
methods. The consultants’ terms of reference are in Appendix 10. 
   
Project Benefits  The  Project  will  raise  education  standards  in  around  500 
and Beneficiaries  madrasahs,  giving  almost  120,000  poor  students,  including 
around 60,000 girls, the immediate benefit of better education. If 
the improved standards are sustained over 10–15 years, roughly 
300,000  poor  students  are  estimated  to  benefit  directly  from 
better education, and about 120,000 students will benefit directly 
from improved academic credentials, leading to better access to 
post-secondary  education  and  formal  paid  employment.  The 
Project  will  directly  and  indirectly  benefit  about  150,000 
households, mainly in the lowest poverty quintile, through fee cost 
savings of about Rp600 billion over 10–15 years, resulting from 
more  resources  flowing  to  private  madrasahs  as  a  result  of 
advocacy and school capacity building.  
The direct household benefits include the opportunity to redirect 
savings to food, shelter, and health care, as well as to save for 
senior  and  post-secondary  education  costs,  which  are  largely 
self-financed. Other indirect benefits to these households include 
(i) improved family health and nutrition, and school attendance; 
(ii) future reduced fertility rates; (iii) greater likelihood of educated 
mothers sending their daughters to school; (iv) reduced risk of 
vulnerability  to  HIV/AIDS  and  child  labor;  and  (v)  greater 
opportunities for jobs and other income-generating activities.  
Other direct beneficiaries will include  (i) about 2,200 teachers 
receiving  professional  upgrading  to  degree  level  and/or 
professional certification; (ii) about 5,300 teachers and principals 
receiving  short-term  pedagogical  training;  (iii)  about  2,500 
madrasah  school  committee  members  receiving  governance

v
awareness raising; (iv) about 500 central, provincial, and district 
MORA  technical  staff  members  receiving  various  forms  of 
training; and (v) about 10,000 local tradesmen and shopkeepers, 
who will directly benefit from income generation related to the 
block-grant  system.  In  the  long  term,  the  upgraded  and  fully 
qualified teachers will be eligible for large salary increases. The 
trained  principals  and  teachers  will  have  enhanced  promotion 
prospects, with potential salary gains.  
Medium-  and  long-term  benefits  include  increased  internal 
efficiency and progression rates, which will result in cost savings 
for parents. Long-term benefits also include increased access for 
madrasah graduates to formal paid employment and consequent 
growth in incomes for the predominantly poor households that 
send their children to low-cost private madrasahs.  
   
Risks and Assumptions  A short-to-medium-term risk is insufficient capacity, especially in 
private madrasahs, to manage resources, including project block 
grants,  to  improve  education.  Insufficient  transparency  and 
accountability in madrasah financial management and accounting 
processes  will  be  mitigated  by  (i)  supporting  Government 
commitment to governance reforms through technical support for 
strengthened  financial  management  and  reporting  in  project 
madrasahs,  along  with  public  disclosure;  (ii)  a  focus  on 
strengthening community governance and accountability through 
community  involvement;  and  (iii)  external  technical  assistance 
(TA) for strengthening performance monitoring and evaluation. 
The  financial  management  capacity  assessment  indicates  that 
MORA’s  financial  management  systems  and  procedures  meet 
ADB requirements. 
A related risk is that project financing and anticipated increased 
government resources will lead to a drop in voluntary parental 
contributions.  The  Project  aims  to  mitigate  these  risks  by 
providing  principal  training,  and  introducing  school-based 
management,  results-based  programming,  and  a  system  of 
quality  improvement,  alongside  transparent  accounting  of  all 
available resources.  
Project schools may find it difficult to retain the teaching staff 
upgraded  over  the  Project  given  their  low  salaries.  The 
Government is planning to introduce substantial incentives and 
subsidies  for  teachers  from  2007,  including  those  in  private 
madrasahs. The risk that physical facilities upgraded under the 
Project  will  not  be  maintained  is  reduced  through  training  in 
preventive maintenance, compulsory for all madrasahs receiving 
funds to improve their facilities. 
Another  medium-term  risk  is  that  proposed  community 
involvement in madrasah development planning may undermine 
the cooperation of the benevolent foundation (yayasan) head, the 
local  religious  leader  (kiai)  and/or  the  principal.  Advocacy 
programs will be carried out to convince the yayasan head, kiai

vi   
and principals of the benefits of community involvement. 
A key assumption is sustained economic growth and protection of 
the  projected  increases  in  public  expenditure  on  education, 
including for public and private madrasahs. A related assumption 
is that MORA and the madrasah system will plan and mobilize the 
anticipated additional resources for madrasahs and spend the 
funds effectively. The Project incorporates specific policy dialogue 
measures  and  assurances  to  offset  these  potential  risks, 
alongside a wide-ranging information campaign outlining these 
new sources of funds and performance-related eligibility criteria. 
   
Technical Assistance  ADB will provide a TA grant in the amount of $995,000 from the 
ADB-funded  TA  program.  The  TA  will  support  independent 
monitoring and evaluation of the project’s programs, activities, 
outputs, outcomes and benefits, and will contribute to the Project 
by  raising  public  confidence  in  the  quality  and  efficiency  of 
madrasah education by issuing reliable performance monitoring 
reports (details of the TA are in Appendix 11). The Government 
will contribute $305,000 to the cost of the TA.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
   
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the Madrasah Education Development Project. The report also 
describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Independent Monitoring and Evaluation of the 
Madrasah Education Development Project, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.   Performance Indicators and Analysis   
 
2.  Recent analysis highlights that accelerated education reform is central to implementing 
the broader development policies of the Government. Economic growth has been 4–6% over 
the past 5 years and is projected to reach 6–7% in 2006–2008. As part of public financial 
management reform, linked to reductions in oil subsidies, the Government is committed to 
allocating a greater share of public expenditure to pro-poor education policy and program 
reforms. The Government recognizes that improving rural access to primary and secondary 
education  is  key  to  enabling  rural  economic  growth  and  increasing  jobs  for  the  poor.  In 
particular,  the  shortage  of  high-quality  secondary  and  post-secondary  school  graduates  is 
recognized  as  a  key  factor  in  the  slow  development  of  rural  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises.1,2 About 2 million–3 million school leavers are projected to join the labor force 
annually over the next 5 years and the number of unemployed 15–24-year-olds is expected to 
rise  faster  in  rural  areas.  Expanding  rural  secondary  education  opportunities  is  central  to 
addressing these concerns.  
 
3.  Policy harmonization across sector agencies and providers in a large education system 
is critical. About 47 million students are enrolled in the 12-year national education system, of 
which  the  first  9  years  (basic  education)  are  compulsory.  The  education  system  is  the 
responsibility  of  the  Ministry  of  National  Education  (MONE),  which  develops  the  overall 
education policy and strategic framework. MONE also manages and regulates the general 
school system, which was decentralized to the districts in 2001. The smaller Islamic education 
sector, which includes madrasahs, is managed and regulated by the Ministry of Religious Affairs 
(MORA)  within  the  national  policy  framework,  although  it  develops  specific  policies  and 
strategies for madrasahs. MORA and the madrasah sector have not been decentralized.  
 
4.  In both sectors a strong public–private partnership aims to achieve the Government’s 
priorities of universal basic education, higher quality and relevance, and expanded participation 
in junior and senior secondary education. While the country has expanded access to primary 
education, poor education quality combined with low participation rates in secondary education 
remains an important concern for the Government as it strives to remain competitive with its 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) neighbors.  
 
5.  Net enrolment rates have stagnated over the past 5 years at around 93% for primary 
and 65% for junior secondary education. About 686,000 primary school students drop out 
annually, including 81,000 from madrasahs. The transition rate from primary to junior secondary

6.  Securing  an  efficient  and  effective  madrasah  system  is  an  important  part  of  the 
Government’s strategy for achieving its key education policy of universal 9-year basic education 
and the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) for basic education and gender equity. The 
new  education  law  emphasizes  the  importance  of  diversifying  partnerships  in  the  drive  to 
achieve universal basic education through the private sector. MONE and MORA are major 
providers. This strong and growing public–private partnership, including a proven willingness of 
parents to contribute, represents a strong foundation for reforms.3 As the madrasah sector 
attracts a substantial proportion of students from the poorest families—the group that has 
proved hardest to draw into basic education—it can complement Government efforts to capture 
and retain these hard-to-reach children. The biggest challenge, and opportunity, lies in junior 
secondary education, where it has been most difficult to increase enrolments, and where the 
madrasah presence is strongest. The madrasahs also provide the opportunity to enroll more 
girls. Some girls in madrasahs would not be in school at all if madrasahs were not available, 
especially after primary school.  
 
7.  In  2004/05,  there  were  6  million  madrasah  students,  or  13%  of  the  total  student 
population. At the junior secondary level, madrasahs accommodate over 20% of all students. 
More than 90% of madrasahs are private, established by benevolent foundations (yayasan) or 
local religious leaders (kiai) in rural areas lacking schools or other education opportunities, and 
they generally have strong community support. Most students are rural poor: 84% of their 
parents have incomes below the regional poverty level. Girls constitute just over half of all 
madrasah  students,  and  a  higher  proportion  at  higher  levels,  and  are  never  segregated. 
Madrasah  students  follow  the  national  curriculum,  sit  the  national  examinations,  and  can 
transfer to general schools. Madrasah ibtidaiyah (MI) are equivalent to general primary schools 
(grades 1–6), madrasah tsanawiyah (MT) to general junior secondary schools (grades 7–9), and 
madrasah aliyah (MA) to general senior secondary schools (grades 10–12).  
 
8.  The Government and external funding agencies give substantial support to general 
education, but investment in madrasahs, especially private ones, has remained low. The Asian 
Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  two  previous  madrasah  projects  supported  mainly  public 
madrasahs, which have improved, but private madrasahs continue to rank poorly on all key 
quality indicators. In the 2006 final examinations, madrasah students trailed behind general-
school students in almost all subjects in almost all provinces, with the biggest disparities at the 
top of the score range. Enabling improved education governance and accountability is another 
key issue, particularly in relation to decentralization, where roles and responsibilities require 
further  refinement.  School  and  madrasah  committees,  granted  more  powers  under 
decentralization, have been slow to exercise greater authority. A summary sector analysis is in

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities   
 
9.  Building on High-Level Commitment to Reform. Current high-level ownership and 
leadership of accelerated education reform constitutes a major opportunity to support education 
development. Comprehensive sector performance assessments and significant organizational 
changes are under way. These processes have been in direct response to direction from the 
President. A key feature of the ongoing policy reforms is a greater focus on institutional reform, 
more  pro-poor  education  financing  policies,  and  more  results-oriented  performance 
management and monitoring systems.  
 
10.  The growing evidence of commitment to policy reform has given Parliament greater 
confidence  in  allocating  more  public  resources  to  education.  Of  Government  spending  on 
education, about  65%  is  channelled  through  regional  budgets  and  the  remainder  centrally 
managed.  Total  Government  spending  (including  external  funding  support)  constitutes  an 
estimated 15.0% of Government current expenditure and about 2.6% of gross domestic product 
(GDP).4 Centrally managed education expenditure will rise from Rp46.9 trillion in 2006 (9.9% of 
the  national  budget)  to  Rp51.3  trillion  in  2007  (10.3%).  Further  substantial  increases  are 
planned from 2007 onward, to be based on a joint national strategic plan being developed by 
MONE and MORA. The share of the MORA education budget in the central education budget is 
expected to be maintained at 21% up to 2011, while the private sector share of the MORA 
education budget is projected to increase from 19% in 2006 to 24% in 2011. This figure will 
increase further as it excludes new programs planned for 2007 that will disproportionately 
benefit the private sector.  
 
11.  Along  with  these  budget  increases,  increased  levels  of  external  assistance  are 
anticipated to be required over the medium term to cover the transitional costs of the madrasah 
education reform program, phased and scaled in line with projected increases in Government 
funding. 
 
12.  Securing the Comparative Advantage of the Madrasah System. Parents’ demand for 
madrasah education is growing and sustained. Lower fees, fee waivers, and a secure, religious 
environment are attractive to many families, especially among the poor, and for girls. The high 
proportion of private madrasahs also encourages strong community participation in managing 
and  financing  education,  including  many  voluntary  and  low-paid  teachers.  Current 
developments provide a unique opportunity to secure these advantages and to establish a well-
financed and high-quality madrasah system. The national Government’s program to subsidize 
school operating budgets, introduced in 2005, increases private madrasah funding, and the new 
teachers' law provides an opportunity to upgrade teachers’ qualifications. Recent changes to 
strengthen  MORA’s  senior  management,  the  development  of  a  new  government  financing 
policy, and the initiation of a MORA strategic framework for 2006–2015 further strengthen this 
opportunity. 
 
13.  There is a strong correlation between teacher academic qualifications, overall school 
effectiveness,  and  improved  learning  outcomes.  Improvement  of  madrasah  education  is 
constrained by a lack of qualified teachers in core subject areas. Almost all MI teachers (83%) 
lack an undergraduate degree, and only 2% have a degree in core teaching subject areas. In

14.  Access to instructional materials and a well-maintained physical environment are also

15.  The madrasah education sector assessment found that a perceived lack of quality and 
relevance of MA schooling was a significant constraint on the transition rate from MT to MA, and 
possibly from MI into MT. Yearly, 20–25% of all MI graduates and over 30% of MT graduates 
fail to continue to the next educational level. Within cycles, the dropout rate has declined 
significantly since 2000, partly because of the introduction of a small scholarship program and 
benevolent yayasan, which often support poor children. Repetition rates are high at the early 
primary level (3–6%). 
 
16.  International research has found that results-oriented governance and management, 
including  school  leadership  that  focuses  on  excellence,  is  key  to  improving  educational 
outcomes. Parental perceptions that schools are well managed is a critical factor in how parents 
judge  school  effectiveness.  District  supervisory  support  systems  are  underdeveloped,  and 
district management of madrasahs is hindered by too few district staff, low capacity, and lack of 
resources. The new school accreditation systems and proposed staff development programs 
provide an opportunity to address these issues. The capacity and commitment to implementing 
madrasah-based management is variable. Communities are represented through madrasah 
committees that are mandated to take part in planning, budgeting, and financial accountability, 
but  not  all  private  madrasahs  have  these  committees.  Madrasah  principals  need  skills 
upgrading to be effective school leaders and managers (73% of MI and 37% of MT principals 
are unqualified). The madrasah sector is poorly represented on district education councils, 
resulting in variable levels of support from local government.  
 
C.  Government Strategy and Policy 
 
17.  A goal of the Medium-Term Development Plan 2005–2009 is to increase access to 
quality education. The plan targets increased enrolment rates in basic and senior secondary 
education and improved education quality. These goals are reflected in the Education Strategic 
Plan 2005–2009 developed by MONE, which sets out the major policy and strategic priorities for 
the next 5 years, including (i) achieving universal access to 9 years of basic education by 2009; 
(ii) expanding net enrolment rates in post-basic education; (iii) raising education standards and 
relevance at all levels, including efficient teacher preparation and deployment; (iv) strengthening 
results-oriented education governance and management systems; (v) improving the results 
orientation  of  sector  planning  and  monitoring  systems;  (vi)  harmonizing  public–private 
partnerships; (vii) ensuring that graduates are regionally competitive; (viii) stimulating a more 
demand-side response to program implementation; and (ix) strengthening quality assurance 
and monitoring systems, particularly school-community and local government accountability 
mechanisms.  As  madrasahs  are  part  of  the  national  education  system,  these  overarching 
priorities apply equally to MORA. Recently, Parliament called for the development of a national 
strategic plan to be prepared jointly by MORA and MONE, to reflect these priorities in one 
national education framework.

D.  Asian Development Bank Sector Strategy 
 
18.  The Project supports the country strategy and program (CSP) 2006–2009 by helping 
improve people’s welfare through accelerated attainment of the MDGs. The CSP identifies 
specific education sector outcomes: (i) improved expansion and equity; (ii) better education 
quality, relevance, and competitiveness; and (iii) enhanced governance, accountability, and 
public image. The Project will contribute to all three outcomes through improved learning for 
poor students, increased relevance and competitiveness of madrasah graduates, strengthened 
school–community governance and school-based management, and increased opportunities for 
poor and/or rural students in selected districts. 
 
19.  A strategic priority for ADB is to help MONE and MORA harmonize their approaches to 
improve quality and quality assurance across primary and secondary education to ensure that 
more students continue to and complete junior and senior secondary education. ADB's sector 
strategy will be implemented through a mix of modalities, designed in line with specific policy 
and  strategic  priorities:  policy-led  program  loans  to  enable  sector-wide  reforms,  and  more

E.  Other External Support and Donor Coordination 
 
20.  ADB has been a leading supporter of Indonesian education. It has provided $2,127 
million in loans and $16 million in TA. Over the past decade, strategic priorities have been to

sector work and advisory TA.   
 
21.  Indonesia’s  political  and  strategic  importance  has  attracted  large  amounts  of  grant

F.  Lessons 
 
23.  A number of key lessons learned from previous quality improvement projects have been 
incorporated into the Project (Appendix 4). The first is the need to focus assistance carefully on 
a targeted set of schools rather than spreading resources thinly across a large number of 
schools. Second, such projects will be more sustainable if activities and financing are built into 
school and district routine operations. Third, a design focus on school and student performance 
standards is more likely to strengthen school─community and district accountability. Fourth, 
support for private schools should target only those with good potential for sustainability. Finally, 
support for quality improvement is more effective when linked to capacity-building support for 
more  results-oriented  school  governance  and  management.  The  project  design  takes  into 
account  all  these  by  (i)  focusing  resources  on  just  500  medium-sized  madrasahs,  (ii) 
strengthening governance systems, (iii) setting national education standards (benchmarks) as 
the main project output, and (iv) channeling over 50% of the project funds directly to the 
madrasahs,  to  be  managed  and  used  by  the  principal  and  madrasah  committee  to  meet 
identified school needs.  
 
24.  Experience shows that channeling funds directly to schools must be guided by clear 
technical directions on the funds’ use, with strict reporting and public disclosure mechanisms. 
The  project  design  includes  comprehensive  financial  reporting  procedures,  community 
participation through madrasah committees, and oversight of school financing under madrasah-
based  management  procedures.  To  improve  accountability,  madrasahs  will  be  required  to 
implement a financial information system for quarterly reporting on funds used and activities. 
The funds will be tied to performance agreements and released only if performance is good. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome   
 
25.  In partnership with the Government and other donors, over the long term the Project is 
expected to help raise levels of educational attainment among new entrants in the labor force 
and increase rates of formal employment and household incomes. The medium-term outcome 
of the Project will be improved quality, efficiency, and effectiveness of primary, junior secondary, 
and senior secondary madrasah education. Key success indicators will include (i) improved 
student performance at all levels, including a reduced gap in quality between the madrasah and 
general-education systems; (ii) reduced district disparities in madrasah student performance, 
with significant improvements in project madrasahs; (iii) improved progression and retention 
rates within the madrasah system; and (iv) more positive community perceptions of madrasah 
education quality.

7 
26.  The overall project design rationale is to combine a carefully selected set of supply-side 
interventions  alongside  a  number  of  key  governance  and  institutional  reforms.  These 
interventions and reforms were selected based on extensive evidence of key determinants of 
quality and internal efficiency improvements. A second dimension of the design rationale is to 
focus these interventions on poor rural districts, with significant concentrations of medium-sized 
private madrasahs, taking account of the need to avoid duplication with other donor-supported 
initiatives. The design is based on well-researched district and school selection criteria and 
significant stakeholder consultations.  
 
27.  Provinces, districts, and madrasahs were selected in phases: provinces first, based on 
high  madrasah  enrolments  and  proximity;  then  districts,  based  on  poverty  incidence,  high 
madrasah enrolments, absence of other foreign-assisted projects, and interest in the Project; 
finally, individual madrasahs in the districts, according to school size, student poverty, teacher 
qualifications, and proximity. Based on these criteria, 27 poor districts were selected in three 
provinces (Central Java, East Java, and South Sulawesi). Within the districts, 500 madrasahs 
were selected (208 MI, 233 MTs, and 59 MA), of which 90% are private. All levels were included 
to support the vertical integration of district madrasah education. A profile of project district and 
madrasahs is in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
B.  Outputs  
 
28.  The Project is designed to produce four outputs, which will help ensure that national 
education  standards  are  met  in  the  critical  areas  of  (i)  teacher  professionalism,  including 
qualifications and performance; (ii) availability of teaching and learning resources and facilities; 
(iii)  internal  efficiency,  especially  in  student  progression  and  transition  rates;  and  (iv) 
governance, management, and accountability. The Project will coordinate extensively with the 
National  Board  of  Education  Standards  and  the  National  Board  of  School-Madrasah 
Accreditation in standards setting and performance monitoring. A TA grant will be provided for 
external monitoring and evaluation. The project design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.  
 
29.  The outputs will be achieved primarily through the financing mechanism of a 3–4-year 
block grant for each madrasah, supported by providers contracted to deliver specific programs 
such  as  teacher  and  principal  qualification  upgrading  and  short-term  pedagogical  training. 
Outputs (ii) and (iii) will be provided through the madrasah block grants. Madrasahs will choose 
from a menu of options responding to their needs as identified in the madrasah development 
plan (MDP), up to a ceiling for schools at different levels. All madrasahs will be required to 
implement a broad range of activities, including not only the upgrading of physical facilities but 
also other quality improvement programs such as teacher qualification and upgrading, remedial 
programs and transition scholarships, and management training. The content of each block 
grant will vary in accordance with the MDP prepared by each madrasah at the beginning of the 
Project and so cannot be specified in advance. Block grants will be released in semi-annual 
tranches based on performance. 
 
  1.  Teacher Professionalism Improved According to National Standards 
 
30.  Professional Qualifications Upgrading and Professional Certification. The Project 
will allow for formal qualification upgrading to degree level for about 800 teachers and 200 
principals. The degree programs will focus on Bahasa Indonesia, English, mathematics, and the 
sciences. Substitute teachers will be provided to replace teachers undergoing the program. The 
Project will also offer about 1,200 degree-qualified teachers and principals the opportunity for

8   
professional  certification.  At  the  national  level,  at  least  30%  of  the  participants  in  degree 
upgrading and 40% in professional certification will be women.  
 
31.  Subject  Content  Upgrading  and  Classroom  Methodology  Training.  Short-term 
training activities driven by demand and needs will also be offered, focusing primarily on subject 
content in the sciences, mathematics, and English, and on training in classroom methodologies. 
About 5,300 teachers in project madrasahs will be able to apply to attend a programmed 
sequence of two 3-week content and methods training activities annually, beginning in year 2 of 
the Project. To respond to the new curriculum, short training programs will be available for 
teachers in core content areas on identifying learning objectives and lesson planning. Specific 
programs to support classroom competencies will also be provided based on requests from the 
network of teacher learning groups in primary and junior secondary schools. In each district, 
female participation in the short-term training will be in accordance with the proportion of eligible 
female teachers for each subject at each level. Common learning resource centers will compete 
to provide the facilities and resources for any non-school-based activities. 
 
32.  Ongoing  Teacher  Support  and  Mentoring.  The  Project  will  help  develop  teacher 
learning groups for primary and junior secondary schools which provide established fora for 
teachers to help each other solve day-to-day teaching and learning problems. Small block 
grants will be provided annually to centrally located madrasahs to establish and support teacher 
learning  groups.  The  Project  will  make  available  200  competitive  block  grants  annually  to 
develop madrasah-based teaching and learning innovations developed by individual teachers, 
teacher learning groups, or school clusters. The madrasah development centers (MDCs) will 
help in strategic planning to develop teacher learning groups, and to facilitate and evaluate 
these activities.  
 
33.  Competitions for Excellence. Local excellence programs such as performance-based 
teacher awards will be supported in each province, including for schools that meet their MDP 
targets. The Project will provide prizes and MDC members will act as judges.  
 
2.  Teaching–Learning Resources and Facilities Upgraded to National 
Standards 
 
34.  Expanding  Textbooks  and  Learning-Support  Materials.  Using  block-grant  funds, 
madrasahs will be able to select textbooks and learning materials in core subject areas from a 
list approved by MORA and to purchase them. A set of instructional materials will be given to all 
teachers completing degree programs. 
 
35.  Upgrading of Facilities, Equipment, Software, and Furniture. The Project will support 
rehabilitation and construction of classrooms, libraries, laboratories, and a limited number of 
health  clinics  as  required,  including  provision  of  appropriate  equipment  and  furniture.  The 
Assistance Scheme for Facilities Improvement, a community-based scheme used successfully 
in previous school and madrasah projects to construct school facilities, will be adopted. Under 
this scheme, facilities upgrading is managed by the principal and school committee, using local 
workers and parental contributions in cash and kind. All new classrooms will be on unoccupied 
land already owned by the school. Supervisors, facilitators, and civil works specialists (from the 
central project management unit [CPMU]) will monitor the facilities upgrading in collaboration 
with the madrasah committee. All construction must comply with earthquake construction safety 
standards. New classrooms may not be built above existing rooms without an assurance from a 
qualified engineer that the existing rooms can bear the weight of a new upper level.

  3.  Internal Efficiency Increased to National Standards 
 
36.  Remedial Programs. The Project will facilitate after-school student remedial programs 
in  MI  and  MT,  supported  by  annual  block  grants  paid  directly  to  madrasahs.  Performance 
reporting  will  include  remedial  class  sizes,  participant  selection  statistics,  subject  areas, 
participant absenteeism, participant satisfaction, and test results.  
 
37.  Transition Programs. To increase transition rates, scholarships will be available for 
poor MI graduates unable to attend MT or general junior secondary schools, and for poor MT 
graduates  unable  to  attend  MA  or  general  senior  secondary  schools.  This  program  will 
complement  the  national  school  operational  budget  program,  which  offsets  the  costs  of 
schooling  for  those  already  in  school,  and  the  national  cash  transfer  program  that  helps 
compensate families for increased fuel costs. At least 50% of the scholars in each district will be 
girls.  
 
38.  Expand Physical Capacity. In areas where demand for madrasah education exceeds 
capacity, and where there are adequate teachers, madrasahs (especially MTs) may request 
support to add new classrooms to expand enrolments. There must be sufficient unoccupied land 
available on the school grounds. Requests may also be made to expand MIs to the MT level in 
line with Government policy to establish rural integrated schools.  
 
  4.  Governance,  Management,  and  Sustainability  Strengthened  to  National 
Standards 
 
39.  Governance  Development.  Governance  at  the  madrasahs  will  be  reinforced  by 
establishing and strengthening madrasah committees. The Project will advocate 30% female 
representation on the committees, which will be responsible for working with madrasah staff to 
develop  MDPs.  Training  in  governance  will  be  provided  to  the  committees.  Decisions  on 
financial allocations from the block grant will be the responsibility of the madrasah with the 
yayasan head and madrasah committee. District governance will be strengthened by greater 
collaboration between the MORA district office and the district education office in planning 
education development. The education development plans of both agencies will be formally 
reviewed  by  the  district  education  council  so  that  it  knows  the  education  needs  of  all 
constituents served by these parallel service delivery systems.  
 
40.  Madrasah-Based Management and Accountability. Madrasah development planning 
and management, and accountability, are critical components of madrasah-based management 
and  the  key  to  successful  madrasah  improvement.  A  series  of  workshops  on  madrasah 
development planning and financial management will be provided to MORA central, provincial 
and district staff, supervisors, madrasah principals, madrasah committee members and yayasan 
heads. Introductory management courses of 3-5 days will be provided to managers first to lay 
the  foundation  for  introducing  madrasah-based  management  (MBM)  and  madrasah 
development  planning  in  project  districts  and  provinces.  These  courses  will  introduce  the 
management skills needed for successful implementation of MBM and madrasah development 
planning.  Subsequent  10-day  workshops  in  madrasah  development  planning,  MBM  and 
financial management (including modules on financial planning, financial reporting, accounting 
and auditing) will include madrasah committee members. After the workshops, 4-year MDPs will 
be prepared and priorities for quality improvement identified by each madrasah. Additional 
training in MBM will be available to principals and yayasan heads and/or kiai throughout the 
project period, including training on the financial management system to be installed in each 
madrasah. This will be linked to the implementation of the block-grant mechanism, with all

training provided by a contractor. Greater transparency will be promoted through oversight by 
madrasah committees and yayasan, and budgets and expenditures will be made public. The 
continued professional development of principals will also be fostered through the principals’ 
learning groups. Further training will be provided throughout the project to MORA provincial and 
district  office  staff  to  support  madrasah-based  management  in  performance  management 
systems, madrasah-based development and advocacy, and data input and report production for 
education management information systems.  
 
41.  Design and Application of a Preventive Maintenance Program. As part of madrasah-
based management, the Project will design and conduct a compulsory 3-day training program in 
preventive maintenance for representatives from each project madrasah and district office. The 
attached TA will monitor the preventive maintenance activities.  
 
42.  Improved  Sector  Management.  Short  courses  in  leadership  development  and 
management  will  be  offered  to  staff  of  the  central,  provincial  and  district  MORA  offices, 
supervisors, principals and yayasan heads, with a focus on results-based management. Gender 
training for managers will also be part of the program.  Six people will be selected from MORA 
central, provincial, or district offices to attend master’s degree programs overseas. Two PhD 
programs  will  be  supported.  All  programs  will  be  in  management  and  evaluation,  with  an 
emphasis  on  results-based  management,  performance-based  planning  and  budgeting, 
accountability,  and  transparency.  At  least  three  of  the  students  for  the  master’s  and  PhD 
programs will be women. 
 
43.  Teaching Learning Assessment and Quality Assurance System Development. A 
provincial madrasah quality assurance working group will be established to support the MDC as 
a partner in project implementation. This group is designed to (i) implement a quality assurance 
system and associated procedures in madrasahs, (ii) perform a training needs assessment for 
quality  assurance  for  madrasahs,  (iii)  organize  training  and  regular  meetings  to  provide 
consultation service to madrasah principals, (iv) review accreditation proposals submitted by 
madrasahs, (v) with MDC prepare a final recommendation for the madrasahs to be accredited, 
and (vi) select and train supervisors and selected principals to become members of the local 
assessor team for madrasah accreditation. A 10-day training program will be provided for 
central,  provincial,  and  district  staff  and  madrasah  principals  and  owners.  At  least  three 
members of each MDC will be certified as assessors, to participate in quality assurance teams 
to certify madrasahs. To strengthen the MORA–MONE partnership, MORA will establish a 
liaison office for the National Board of Education Standards and the National Board of School-
Madrasah Accreditation..  
 
44.  Advocacy and Public Information Programs. Madrasah development forums (MDFs) 
will be established in project provinces and districts, consisting of yayasan heads and/or kiai, 
principals, teachers, or other community members. The MDF will lobby for madrasah concerns 
and promote appreciation of their positive contributions. The Project will offer advocacy training, 
including information on government resources available to madrasahs, lobbying strategies, and 
techniques for using the media; and will establish a national madrasah links website. The 
Project will support MDF meetings and development and delivery of media materials. 
 
C.  Special Features   
 
45.  Quality Assurance and Benchmarking. The new National Education Standards and 
associated accreditation criteria are the lynchpin of the project design, unlike previous projects 
that targeted incremental quality improvements. This will make it easier to measure results and

11 
assess project success. The meeting of accreditation standards for schools and qualification 
standards  for  teachers  will  result  in  tangible  and  measurable  benefits  for  the  project 
beneficiaries, thus providing an additional incentive to support the Project. 
 
46.  Funds Channeled Directly to End Users. To empower madrasahs and communities, 
and encourage greater community involvement in the planning and budget process, project 
funds will be channeled directly to madrasahs based on approved MDPs. This will increase the 
transparency of fund flows and reduce the opportunity for possible fund misuse when different 
levels of government bureaucracy are involved. An objective of the project design was that at 
least 50% of funds should flow directly to recipients to reduce overhead costs and maximize 
project impact at the beneficiary level.  
 
47.  Community  Monitoring  and  Evaluation.  The  Project’s  monitoring  and  evaluation 
framework is unusual in education projects in that it institutionalizes community involvement. 
Interviews and discussions will be held with madrasah committee members, yayasan heads, 
parents,  and  students  on  their  perceptions  of  madrasahs,  quality  improvements  needed, 
perceived  problems,  and  proposals  for  solutions.  This  information  will  form  a  valuable 
supplement to the quantitative data from the project monitoring information system (PMIS).

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
  1.  Project Management 
 
50.  The Executing Agency for the Project will be MORA which, with the support of the 
Directorate  General  of  Islamic  Education  of  MORA,  will  be  responsible  for  the  overall 
management of the Project. A project steering committee (PSC) will be established to guide the

members will include representatives of MORA, the Ministry of Finance (MOF), the National 
Development Planning Agency (Bappenas), and MONE. The MORA secretary general will chair

Members of the PTC will include representatives of MORA, MOF, and MONE. The director of

51.  MORA will establish the CPMU, under the guidance of the project director. The CPMU 
will be responsible for day-to-day project implementation, planning and budgeting, procurement, 
disbursement, monitoring, supervising, and overseeing implementation at province, district, and 
madrasah levels, and submitting the required reports to the Government and ADB. The CPMU 
will have about 15 staff members, including MORA staff members and consultants working

project province, a project coordinating committee will be established to oversee provincial

head will come from the MORA provincial education division, and will be assisted by finance 
and accounting, procurement and works, and monitoring and evaluation staff, supported by

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Project Benefits and Impacts 
 
69.  Social Benefits. The Project will raise education standards in around 500 madrasah 
schools, thereby giving 120,000 students, including around 60,000 girls, the immediate benefit 
of better education. If the improved standards are sustained over 10–15 years, roughly 300,000 
students will benefit directly from better education, and about 140,000 students will benefit 
directly from improved academic credentials, leading to improved access to post-secondary 
education and formal paid employment. Over the same period, the Project will benefit directly 
and indirectly about 150,000 households, mainly in the lowest poverty quintile. Through the 
increased resources flowing to private madrasahs resulting from advocacy and school capacity 
building, parental contributions will be reduced. Fee cost savings to these households are 
conservatively estimated at Rp600 billion over 10–15 years.9 The direct household benefits 
include the opportunity to redirect these savings to food, shelter, and health care costs, as well 
as the opportunity to save for subsequent senior and post-secondary education costs, which are 
largely self-financed. Other indirect benefits include (i) improved family health and nutrition, and 
school attendance; (ii) future reduced fertility rates; (iii) greater likelihood of educated mothers 
sending their daughters to school; (iv) reduced risk of vulnerability to HIV/AIDS and child labor; 
and (v) more jobs and income-generating activities.  
 
70.  Other direct beneficiaries will include (i) about 2,200 teachers receiving professional 
upgrading  to  degree  level;  (ii)  about  5,300  teachers  and  principals  receiving  short-term 
pedagogical training; (iii) about 2,500 madrasah committee members receiving governance 
awareness raising; (iv) about 500 central, provincial, and district MORA technical staff receiving 
various forms of training; and (v) about 10,000 local tradesmen and shopkeepers, who will 
directly benefit from income generation related to the block-grant system. In the longer term, the 
upgraded teachers will benefit from at least a doubling of their salaries. The trained principals 
and teachers will have enhanced promotion prospects, with potential salary gains. Other indirect 
beneficiaries will include madrasah committee members, who will be empowered through their 
participation in school affairs, and local construction workers and their families involved in 
school rehabilitation. Medium- and long-term benefits include increased internal efficiency and 
progression rates, which will result in cost savings for parents. Long-term benefits also include 
increased access for madrasah graduates to formal paid employment and consequent growth in 
incomes for the predominantly poor households that send their children to low-cost private 
madrasahs. A summary poverty reduction and social analysis is in Appendix 12. 
 
71.  Environment and Social Safeguards. The Project will upgrade and rehabilitate school 
facilities,  with  no  negative  environmental  or  resettlement  impact  as  no  land  acquisition  or 
resettlement  is  required.  Some  new  classrooms  will  be  added  to  existing  schools  but  on 
unoccupied land already owned by the madrasahs. Communities will be involved in decisions 
about construction, which will help mitigate negative environmental impacts. There will be no 
encroachment on indigenous peoples’ territory (impact category C). 
 
72.  Economic Benefits. The most significant long-term economic benefit will come from 
increases  in  earnings  of  madrasah  graduates  with  better  education  attainment  and  higher 
productivity, resulting from improved education. In economic terms, the benefit of education is

73.  An immediate, positive financial and economic impact will be increased resources for 
private madrasahs in project districts and schools. A large proportion of these resources will be 
channelled directly to the poorest students. In the short to medium term, increased advocacy 
and information about available Government funding will ensure that madrasahs become more 
adept at accessing resources. In the long term, as funding becomes better linked to school 
accreditation and performance levels, an important impact will be that resources for madrasahs 
become more predictable and sustainable. 
 
74.  Fiscal  Impact.  A  financial  plan has  been  prepared  that  projects  and  identifies  the 
funding sources to ensure that adequate funds will be available to finance project expenditures. 
The annual fiscal impact of the Project has been estimated on the assumption that GDP will 
continue to grow at 5%, and that the ratio of public and education expenditure to GDP will 
remain unchanged. Project-related expenditures will increase annually and reach $71.4 million 
by  the  Project’s  end,  with  the  Government  share  at  $21.4  million.  Several  Government 
commitments will terminate at the Project’s end. The continuing additional incremental costs of 
$0.5 million annually after the Project ends will add $2.5 million to the total in 2012–2017. This is 
sustainable, given the size of the projected education budget. Some efficiency gains as well as 
strengthened teacher competencies and management capacity will have long-term benefits. 
The Government’s annual commitment for the Project as a percentage of the MORA budget 
ranges from 0.4% to 1.2%, and averages 1.1% over the project life. At the madrasah level, 
sustainability  will  be  enhanced  through  the  school  operational  budget  program,  improved 
quality, governance, management, and advocacy, resulting in increased demand for madrasah 
education, better resource mobilization, and greater cost-efficiency. 
 
B.  Project Risks and Assumptions 
 
75.  Macro Level. A potential strategic risk is the longer-term sustainability of the policy 
reform process with continued, committed leadership and ownership. Reform programs have 
often been disrupted by changes at senior levels in MORA or MONE. This seems less likely 
over the next decade given the strong interest of parliamentarians to demonstrate education 
progress to their electorates; an ongoing process of extensive consultation between MONE, 
MORA, and Parliament on the Education Strategic Plan 2005–2009 and MORA strategic plans; 
and sustained public consultations on rights and responsibilities associated with the reform 
program.

76.  An uncertain fiscal climate and unforeseen developments (e.g., natural disasters and 
volatile oil prices) may undermine the predictability of Government resources for madrasah 
education, especially the significant transitional costs associated with the policy reforms. This 
also appears less of a threat now than in the past because of (i) the Government's evident 
preparedness to direct increased resources to the social sectors and specific pro-poor targeted 
reforms, (ii) extensive policy dialogue with donors on macroeconomic stabilization and pro-poor 
public expenditure management, and (iii) medium-term increases in external assistance that will 
help offset education reform transitional costs. 
 
77.  Project  Level.  Insufficient  transparency  and  accountability  in  Government  financial 
management and accounting processes are a potential project risk, which will be mitigated by (i) 
support  for  Government  commitment  to  governance  reforms  through  technical  support  for 
strengthened  financial  management  and  reporting  in  project  madrasahs,  along  with  public 
disclosure; (ii) a focus on strengthening community governance and accountability through 
community involvement; and (iii) external TA for strengthening performance monitoring and 
evaluation and public information systems. The financial management capacity assessment 
(Supplementary  Appendix  J)  indicates  that  MORA’s  financial  management  systems  and 
procedures meet ADB requirements. 
 
78.  Project madrasahs may find it difficult to retain better-qualified teaching staff given their 
low salaries. Government plans to introduce substantial financial incentives for teachers fulfilling 
qualification standards, having full teaching loads, and living in remote areas will reduce this 
risk. To prevent deterioration of facilities, training in preventive maintenance will be compulsory 
for  all  madrasahs  receiving  funds  for  facilities  improvement.  The  long-term  financial 
sustainability of private madrasahs remains a risk, which the Project will address in several 
ways. The upgraded and expanded madrasahs should attract more students and, hence, more 
fee revenue. Advocacy training will help ensure that madrasahs are better equipped to take 
advantage of the increased Government support. Lastly, madrasah development planning will 
reinforce community involvement in madrasah operations, which usually brings with it greater 
community support. The benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh the costs. There is a 
potential risk that yayasan and principals may be reluctant to accept community involvement in 
madrasah decision making. Advocacy programs will help convince them of the benefits of 
community  involvement,  particularly  community  contributions  to  MDP  implementation. 
Partnership agreements signed with the Project will specify these contributions. 
 
79.  A  key  assumption  is  sustained  economic  growth  and  protection  of  the  projected 
increases in public expenditure on education, including for public and private madrasahs. A 
related  assumption  is  that  MORA  and  the  madrasah  system  will  plan  and  mobilize  the 
anticipated additional resources for madrasahs and spend the funds effectively. The Project 
incorporates specific policy dialogue measures and assurances to offset these potential risks, 
alongside  a  wide-ranging  information  campaign  outlining  these  new  sources  of  funds  and 
performance-related eligibility criteria

EDUCATION SECTOR ANALYSIS AND MADRASAH PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENT 
 
A.  Education Sector Context and Performance Overview 
 
1.  Indonesia has shown a number of significant education sector achievements. Overall 
enrolments at all levels of education have increased. Net enrolment rates in primary and junior 
secondary  education  are  an  estimated  93%  and  62%,  which  are  comparable  with  Asian 
neighbors (e.g., Philippines—primary 94%, junior secondary 55%). In addition, the gap between 
male and female enrolments has fallen substantially. Internal efficiency rates are encouraging 
with repetition and dropout rates below 3%. Higher education enrolments have reached 2.8 
million through a diverse mix of public and private providers. The 1997 crisis barely affected this 
record because of the rapid introduction of student scholarships and school grants programs to 
retain children in school.1  
2.  Another achievement has been to diversify partnerships in education, through the private 
sector. The Ministry of National Education (MONE) and the Ministry of Religious Affairs (MORA) 
are major providers. This strong and growing public–private partnership, including a proven 
willingness of parents to contribute, represents a strong foundation for future reforms, especially 
at post-basic education levels.2 Another achievement has been the introduction of an extensive 
legislative and regulatory program, especially related to pro-poor sector financing and minimum 
service standards. MORA remains a largely centralized ministry, although selected functions are 
delegated to provincial and district offices. 
3.  Despite these achievements, a number of issues need to be addressed if Millennium 
Development Goals (MDG) and Education for All (EFA) goals of universal access to high-quality 
basic education and gender equity are to be assured. Net primary, junior secondary, and senior 
secondary enrolment rates are stagnating. Participation is being constrained by a number of 
factors, including (i) cost barriers, especially formal and informal fees; (ii) distance to school, 
especially for junior- and senior secondary education in remote and rural areas; (iii) extreme 
urban–rural variations in per-student funding; and (iv) growing evidence that a perceived decline 
in quality is beginning to affect demand for education.  
4.  Another key demand-side issue is that improved access to primary and junior secondary 
education  is  not  a  sufficient  condition  to  maintain  or  stimulate  additional  demand.  Easier 
opportunities to progress to senior secondary education, higher education, and other post-
secondary education and training opportunities as an avenue to formal sector paid employment 
are  critical,  especially  among  the  poorest  families,  who  face  greater  real  and  perceived 
opportunity costs. There is also growing demand for second-chance education opportunities, 
through more relevant and labor market oriented non-formal and informal education and skills 
training. 
5.  Growing  public  awareness  of  Government's  new  National  Education  Standards  is 
creating both opportunities and risks. Linked to the introduction of widely published examination 
results,  it  is  an  opportunity  to  strengthen  community  governance  and  accountability 
mechanisms. The standards are also being used to lobby for and mobilize additional resources 
from the Government, evidenced by the substantial increase in central MONE funding since

6.  Nevertheless, there are a number of potential risks. Unless access and quality indicators 
are improved quickly in line with Government policy and minimum service standards (MSS) 
targets, public confidence and demand may decline. A second risk is that unless many supply-
side issues are addressed, demand may decline. These supply-side factors include (i) reducing 
urban–rural disparities in secondary school access, (ii) eliminating disparities in the distribution 
of qualified teachers and textbook availability, (iii) improving school building conditions, and (iv) 
beginning to equalize per student spending and eliminating basic education school fees. 
7.  Another potential risk is that unless cost-efficiency issues are dealt with quickly, sector 
financing may not be sustainable. Improving the teaching and non-teaching staff utilization 
rates, reducing dropout and repetition rates, increasing primary-secondary transition rates and 
optimizing the use of school facilities are recognized as key challenges. Simultaneously, sector 
planning  and  management  needs  to  become  more  results-oriented,  using  MSS-related 
performance criteria, as the basis for sector performance monitoring and evaluation. Parliament 
and ministers of MONE and MORA recognize that any additional funding for the sector needs to 
be justified by better results. 
8.  Another  potential  risk  is  that  the  organizational  and  management  arrangements  in 
MONE and MORA will continue to be insufficiently realigned with new assigned functions and 
responsibilities,  under  decentralization  or  selective  deconcentration.  In  particular,  central 
strategic  planning,  budget  management,  and  performance  monitoring  systems  remain 
underdeveloped. Results-oriented information flow and management systems at various levels 
are  also  limited.  Unless  these  systems  are  improved,  justifying  any  further  reforms  and 
mobilizing additional funds will be problematic. 
B.  Madrasah Sector Assessment and Strategic Response: Project Rationale 
 
9.  The project rationale and design is in response to the broad policy, institutional, and 
financing features derived from this sector assessment. In addition, the project design responds 
to the unique opportunities, challenges, and potential risks facing the madrasah education 
sector.3,4 The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has a comparative advantage given its extensive 
history  and  experience  of  being  the  lead  aid  agency  supporting  madrasah  education 
development over the past decade, providing an opportunity to consolidate and extend the 
impact of previous support. 
 
10.  There is evidence of sustained and growing demand for madrasah education. Madrasah 
students now represent 13% of total enrollments in Indonesia. Enrollment is growing rapidly. 
Average annual growth rates of madrasah enrollment 1998/99 to 2003/04 well outpaced that of 
the general education system. The growth rate at primary level in madrasah ibtidaiyah (MI) was 
1.97%  in  2003/04  compared  with  a  general  primary-school  growth  rate  of  0.22%.  The 
comparative growth rates for junior secondary level in madrasah tsanawiyah (MTs) and in 
general junior secondary schools were 3.86% and -0.11%, respectively. The rates for senior 
secondary level in madrasah aliyah (MA) and general senior secondary schools were 11.89% 
and 3.03%, respectively.5  
 
11.  Sustaining the madrasah education system is critical if MDG and EFA goals are to be 
achieved and sustained. Madrasahs encourage poor and disadvantaged students to attend.

were female, compared with 48.5% in general schools. Female students are not segregated in

positions. Only 13.1% of principals in madrasahs are female. 
 
12.  The madrasah system provides a key vehicle for ensuring the crowding in of private 
contributions for education and ensuring active participation of community groups in school 
governance and management. Over 90% of madrasahs are private.  About 81% of students are 
in private madrasahs and 85% of the teachers. In some instances, madrasahs are owned by 
individuals or families. Most private madrasahs are small, with fewer than 200 students. These 
smaller private madrasahs are close to their communities and are often run by local religious 
leaders (kiai) or foundations (yayasan).  
 
13.  Nevertheless, these comparative advantages of the madrasah schools are fragile. As 
parents become more aware of Government's minimum standards, especially characterized by 
available instruction materials and qualified teachers, there is a risk that demand will decline. 
Equally, unless parents are increasingly guaranteed the quality and relevance of madrasah 
education,  evidenced  by  comparative  student  examination  performance,  employability,  and 
admission  into  further  education,  there  is  a  serious  risk  that  madrasah  schooling  may  be 
undermined. The private madrasah school system is particularly vulnerable to these risks. A key 
project rationale is to address these demand- and supply-side issues through targeted support 
and an extensive advocacy program.  
 
14.  A critical issue is to improve the student performance in madrasahs and, simultaneously, 
reduce performance differentials between madrasahs and general schools. For example, in 
2003,  junior  and  secondary  examination  failure  rates  in  madrasahs  were  11%  and  15%, 
compared with 4% and 7% respectively in MONE-managed schools. This means madrasah 
graduates are less competitive in gaining admission to senior secondary schooling, higher 
education,  and  other  post-secondary  opportunities.  Equally,  there  is  evidence  that  senior 
secondary madrasah graduates are less competitive in the labor market and perceived as less 
employable.  
 
15.  There are a number of consequences of this difference in quality between general 
schools and madrasahs. Firstly, the lower pass rates in junior secondary constitute a constraint 
on access to senior secondary education, which is still merit-driven and competitive. Secondly, 
the  recognized  underperformance  in  junior  secondary  madrasah  schooling  contributes  to 
variable  demand  at  this  level.  Thirdly,  the  comparatively  poorer  performance  at  senior 
secondary level limits madrasah graduates’ admission to higher education and formal, paid 
jobs.6  
 
16.  Another key indicator of the quality of madrasahs is their official categorization. Only a 
small proportion of madrasahs have the highest ranking. Public madrasahs are all considered

a result, only 70% of primary madrasah students progress to junior secondary madrasahs, often

issue. 
 
19.  Many of these features are a result of insufficient resources in madrasahs, especially 
private ones, which are heavily reliant on small fees and voluntary teachers. In the long term, 
financing prospects are encouraging with the projected increases in MORA central budgets, the 
expansion  of  school  operational  budget  mechanisms  under  MORA  management,  and 
government financing of teacher upgrading and retraining. A critical challenge to MORA will be 
to set these additional resources within an overall medium- and long-term policy and strategic 
framework, harmonized with MONE, as Parliament is demanding. 
 
20.  Nevertheless, the extent of proposed madrasah education reforms will require additional 
transitional support, especially to address immediate quality-oriented supply-side interventions, 
especially  teacher  and  management  development,  selective  facilities  rehabilitation,  and 
instructional materials shortfalls. Expansion of the results-oriented MORA block grant system is 
particularly crucial to enable more results-oriented school governance and management and 
associated  capacity  building.  Assisting  with  these  transitional  costs,  alongside  other  aid 
agencies (e.g., Australian Agency for International Development [AusAID] and the United States 
Agency  for  International  Development  [USAID]),  while  supporting  longer-term  policy  and 
institutional reform, is central to the project rationale. 
 
21.  Avoiding the crowding out of parental and community contributions through project and 
Government  funding  is  critical.  Strengthening  school-based  planning  and  management  is 
another  key  project  feature.  The  aim  will  be  to  assist  madrasah  governing  bodies  to  use 
additional funding, alongside its own, to assure quality-oriented inputs and activities. At the 
same  time,  it  is  recognized  that  strengthening  central,  provincial,  district,  and  school 
performance monitoring systems is important for assessing school effectiveness and taking 
action. In this way, public confidence in the madrasah system will be sustained.

AND DISBURSEMENT PROCEDURES 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
1.  One key feature of the Project is to encourage madrasahs to become more innovative 
and proactive in planning and managing their own educational programs based on their unique 
situation  and  needs.  Under  a  madrasah-based  management  system,  each  madrasah  will 
prepare a 4-year madrasah development plan (MDP) covering all aspects of its operations with 
the objective of improving the quality of education it offers to the students. The MDP will be 
results-based, and will consist of activities and a budget that specifies sources of funding for 
each activity, tied to specific performance indicators. The Project will provide block grants that 
will constitute one source of funding to be used for activities of the MDP that are eligible for 
funding under the project rules. Other activities will be funded from alternative sources such as 
the Ministry of Religious Affairs (MORA) budget, local budget, and community participation.  
 
B.    Disbursement Procedures for Block Grants 
 
2.  To be eligible for a block grant, the project madrasahs will develop a 4-year MDP. In the 
first  year  of  the  Project,  training  and  technical  support  will  be  provided  for  the  principal, 
teachers,  staff,  yayasan,  and  members  of  the  madrasah  committee  in  the  process  and 
techniques of preparing an MDP. Facilitators hired by the Project will help madrasahs prepare, 
implement, and monitor MDPs. The madrasahs will submit the MDP to the district coordination 
unit (DCU) at district MORA office for review and evaluation. After the MDP is finalized and 
evaluated by the facilitators together with the DCU, the plan will be submitted to the provincial 
coordinating unit (PCU) for further review, endorsement, consolidation, and submission to central 
project management unit (CPMU) for review and approval. 
 
3.  A block grant will be earmarked for each madrasah to implement its MDP activities. The 
block grant will be disbursed in semiannual tranches over the course of the Project, based on 
MDP project accomplishment and commitment. The block grant for the first year will be based 
on the approved expenses planned for the first year of MDP activities. The subsequent releases 
from the Treasury, Ministry of Finance (KPPN, MOF) will be based on reports from madrasahs 
on the progress achieved, funds utilization, and committed funds, submitted to CPMU through 
the PCU and DCU.  
 
4.  Upon approval of each MDP, MORA will prepare a decree (surat keputusan), for the 
Directorate General of Islamic Education to sign and issue, to authorize financing of the MDP by 
a block grant. The decree will contain the name of the madrasah, bank account information, and 
the amount of funding. The decree will be sent to the recipient madrasah through the PCU and 
the DCU for recording and monitoring. The project manager and the madrasah will sign a multi-
year contract based on the approved MDP. On the basis of this contract, the project manager 
will prepare a payment order (surat perintah membayar), to be signed and issued by the director 
general as project director, to KPPN (Jakarta). KPPN will send a disbursement order (surat 
perintah pencairan dana) to its local operational bank copied to the CPMU and Bank Indonesia, 
and  will  subsequently  order  the  local  operational  bank  to  transfer  the  block  grant  to  the 
madrasah’s bank account.  
 
C.  Reporting and Replenishment  
 
5.  Each project madrasah will submit to the PCU through the DCU quarterly financial and 
annual project reports, which will be consolidated into quarterly and annual reports. The PCU 
will monitor progress toward achievement of targets and activities. Upon satisfactory review of
