financial and other reports by the PCU and CPMU, the second tranche of the first year will be 
released from KPPN to the madrasah bank accounts in the same manner as for the first 
tranche. The same review and approval of reports will be needed to release the subsequent 
tranches of the block grant. 
 
6.  Within 3 months of each fund transfer from KPPN to the madrasah bank account, the 
CPMU will prepare the statement of expenditures (SOEs) summarizing the status and use of the 
block grant provided to the madrasahs by district for the entire province. The SOEs will be 
prepared by category of expenditure based on the approved MDP programs and activities, with 
an SOE limit of $100,000. To replenish the imprest account, the CPMU will prepare withdrawal 
applications  based  on  district  SOEs,  attach  the  relevant  madrasah  bank  statements  and 
payment  order,  and  submit  them  to  MOF  for  endorsement  and  submission  to  ADB,  for 
replenishment and liquidation of the imprest account. The records of transfer of funds from 
KPPN to madrasah bank accounts according to the approved block-grant budget tranche (MDP) 
will serve as the basis for SOEs.  
 
D.  Accounting and Auditing  
 
7.  Each  recipient  madrasah  will  be  required  to  keep  separate  accounts,  records,  and 
evidence of payments and use of the block grant for reference and audit by the PCU, CPMU, 
and Government Audit Agency. Every quarter, the PCU will audit the accounts and records of a 
sample of madrasahs to ensure that the block grant is properly used in accordance with the 
approved plan and budget. If there are irregularities, corruption cases, and fraudulent practices 
involved in the use of the block-grant funds, the PCU will report them to the CPMU for further 
investigation  and  administrative  and  legal  actions  against  the  madrasahs  and  individuals 
involved.  The  CPMU  will  report  to  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  issue  an  order 
suspending the activities at the particular madrasahs until the cases are satisfactorily resolved. 
When block-grant funds are used improperly, fund recovery will be determined by the CPMU 
investigative panel in consultation with ADB. 
 
8.  The CPMU will also organize a semiannual audit of the accounts and records of the use 
of the block grant funds at a sample of the project madrasahs in each district. The independent 
monitoring and evaluation team may be requested to conduct the audit and submit reports of its 
findings to the CPMU as parts of its responsibilities and terms of reference. If there are cases of 
irregularities, corruption, and fraudulent practices, the same procedures as described above will 
be adopted.  
 
9.  MORA will request the Government Audit Agency to audit the accounts and records of 
the  recipient  madrasahs  on  the  use  of  the  block  grant  funds  in  accordance  with  the 
Government’s standard practices. The Government Audit Agency will submit its reports of the 
findings to CPMU and the concerned government agencies to ensure that the block grant funds 
are properly used as approved and that irregularities, corruption cases, and fraudulent practices 
will be properly handled to deter them. 
 
10.  MORA will also request the Government Audit Agency to audit the project accounts and 
statement of expenditures and provide a management letter covering internal controls and 
procedures associated with the maintenance of project accounts and preparation of audited 
project accounts. Such audited project accounts should be submitted to ADB no later than 9 
months after the close of the fiscal year to which they relate. Independent monitoring and 
evaluation will also be undertaken during project implementation.

A.  Macroeconomic and Sectoral Analysis 
1.  The economy has recovered from the Asian monetary crisis of 1997, with annual gross 
domestic product (GDP) growth at about 5%. Before the crisis, economic growth was largely 
investment  driven,  with  gross  investments  to  GDP  averaged  at  about  30%,  which  was 
principally driven by private consumption, with services sector growth twice the manufacturing 
sector  (6.2%  vs.  3.6%).  Post  crisis  (1998–2005),  investment  and  net  exports  show  mixed 
performance with annual gross investments to GDP declining to below 20%. This structural 
change has implications for job creation and its effect on employment and income levels. The 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) poverty assessment1 indicates poverty incidence declining from 
11% to 24% in a relatively short period, but a large portion of the population subsist just above 
the poverty line and remains highly vulnerable.  
 
2.  Positively, the recent reduction in oil subsidies is designed to sustain macroeconomic 
stability  and  enable  redirection  of  a  greater  share  of  public  expenditure  to  education.  For 
example,  in  March  2005,  Government  introduced  a  30%  rise  in  fuel  prices,  with  savings

neighbors  (e.g.,  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  and  Viet  Nam).  The  projected  increased

strategy and the rural economic diversification program.  
3.  Another impetus is to raise Indonesia's ranking from the bottom third of the global 
economic  competitiveness  index.2 A  quarter  of  Indonesian  firms  think  that  the  inadequate 
workforce  skills  are  a  key  obstacle  to  their  profitability  and  competitiveness,  a  growing

arrangements.3 This is a key factor also for stimulating rural agricultural and small and medium-

B.  Economic Justification 
5.  Over the medium to long term, a key economic justification for the project focus on 
improving and assuring madrasah education quality is that it will help raise the productivity and 
income level of graduates when they enter the workforce. Senior secondary school madrasah 
graduates will become more directly competitive in the formal paid employment sector. Through 
increased admissions to higher education, they will also be more competitive in the higher-
earning professional employment market. In macroeconomic terms, the increased number of 
well-qualified  madrasah  graduates  will  contribute  to  Indonesia's  regional  and  international 
competitiveness, which will attract foreign and local investment. 
 
6.  Another project focus is to improve the reputation of madrasah education among parents 
and  employers  by  assuring  them  that  necessary  education  standards  will  be  met  and  by 
conducting key supply-side interventions. In this way, the subjective household discount rate for 
education will move closer to the actual market discount rate, and the rational expectation of 
future wages will also rise because madrasah graduates will have equal access with general 
school  graduates  to  formal  sector  jobs.  In  other  words,  the  Project  will  contribute  to  the 
increased likelihood of parents continuing to contribute to the costs of madrasah education, 
thereby increasing the overall level of resources and sustainability of sector outcomes. 
 
7.  Ultimately, sustained demand for educational quality is related to higher productivity. 
Parents value quality to the degree that they perceive a positive relationship between improved 
quality and improved incomes later in the labor force. Surveys have shown that parents want 
better-quality  education,  but  are  unable  to  afford  the  increased  cost  of  quality  education. 
Employers also value quality in education, to the degree that it improves productivity. Studies 
have shown that graduates with different types of education sort themselves into different types 
of jobs at different levels of productivity. Madrasah graduates have less access to mid-level 
incomes and jobs.7 A key project objective is to redress this disadvantage.

instructional materials; (iii) strong school leadership focusing on academic excellence; and (iv) 
transparent, accountable, and results-oriented school governance and management systems.

13.  The project design will have a positive impact on reducing poverty and improving social 
development. There is evidence that graduates of a 6-year primary cycle earn much more than 
students who have completed only 5 years and that there are small differences in earnings 
between school leavers with 3 or 4 or 5 years of primary school (McGinn, 1989). As noted 
above, children from poorer and less-educated families are more apt to leave school before or 
on  completing  basic  education.  Their  lower  levels  of  human  capital  can  be  expected  to 
perpetuate  their  families'  marginal  economic  status  intergenerationally.  Intergenerational 
poverty  cycles  arise  through  strong  relationships  between  parental  education,  household 
poverty, and children's educational achievements. Research has shown a significant correlation 
between initial education inequality and reduced income growth, pointing to the need to break 
this cycle.10 
 
                                                 
8  The wage gap appears to be caused by differential distribution of madrasah graduates into unfavorable jobs: as 
unpaid workers (vs. paid employees for general school graduates) and in agriculture (vs. trade for general school 
graduates). 
9  World Bank. 2002. Policy Research Working Paper 2881– Returns on Investment in Education. Washington, DC. 
10 ADB. 2004. Effect of Asset Distribution on Growth and Poverty Reduction. Manila.

62  Appendix 13 
14.  There is significant evidence that retaining children from poor families, especially girls, in 
junior  secondary  schools  correlates  strongly  with  reduced  risk  for  HIV/AIDS  vulnerability, 
especially in remote and cross-border areas. The project focus on expanding primary and 
secondary education opportunities in these areas is therefore a key design consideration.  
 
E.  Education Financing Outlook 
15.  The Project will enable movement towards increased funding for education from the 
national  budget.  While  the  Government  has  set  policies  and  programs  to  make  funding 
equitable and proportionally allocated to general schools and madrasahs to improve their quality 
and meet national education standards, there has been a disproportionate allocation so far 
between madrasahs and general schools. The project support will help meet the transitional 
costs of the proposed madrasah education reforms. 
 
16.  The  project  focus  on  attaining  national  education  standards  and  accreditation  for 
madrasahs, especially private ones, will help assure quality-oriented inputs and sustainability. 
The Government will revise the BOS funding policy based on minimum fixed costs for schools to 
run  the  teaching–learning  process,  in  lieu  of  the  previous  per  capita  student  allocation. 
Government commitment to education is firm and has been continuously growing in recent 
years, thus lending considerable empirical weight to projected fiscal requirements.  
 
17.  The fiscal outlook and prospects of sustainability of sector financing are encouraging. 
The  economic  outlook  is  favorable,  with  real  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  expected  to 
continue to grow by around 5% from 2006 onward.11 Public expenditure on education is low—
about  1.7%  of  GDP  in  2006.  The  recent  increases  in  education  budget  allocations  are 
consistent with government commitment to meet constitutional targets. Nevertheless, the project 
focus on strengthening school governance and management is designed to ensure that parental 
contributions to madrasahs are not crowded out and increased government and project funding 
is additional and not substitute financing. 
 
18.  A financial plan in the form of cost table showing fiscal impact of the Project has been 
prepared and provides funding sources necessary to ensure the availability of adequate funds 
to finance project expenditures. This applies to the entire implementation period to ensure that 
funds are available to cover both capital and recurrent expenditures over the entire operating 
period of the loan. The Government’s share in the Project is estimated at $21.4 million over 5 
years  and  will  consist  mainly  of  madrasah  block  grants  for  quality  improvement,  staff 
development, consultant services, and incremental recurrent cost due to the Project. Given 
GDP growth rates of 5% per annum and current public expenditure projections for education, 
the Government contribution is feasible and sustainable. 
 
19.  It is estimated that project-related expenditures will increase annually and reach $71.4 
million during the last year of the Project in accordance with the increasing number of teachers 
and  non-teaching  staff  required  for  incremental  madrasah  classes  and  operation  and 
maintenance expenses. Given the size of the projected education sector budget, the continuing 
additional incremental costs of $2.5 million annually after the project period would add $0.5 
million to the total in 2009–2010, which is judged affordable and sustainable.
